questions.text: A patient is given 100% oxygen at the end of anesthesia after discontinuing nitrous oxide (N2O) and extubating. This practice primarily aims to prevent which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diffusion Hypoxia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Diffusion Hypoxia : After discontinuation of N2O, the rapid diffusion of N2O out of the blood into the alveoli can dilute alveolar oxygen. Providing 100% oxygen prevents the dilution of alveolar oxygen, thus preventing diffusion hypoxia.
  • • Option A. Diffusion Hypoxia
  • • Option B. Second Gas Effect : This refers to the increased uptake of a second inhaled anesthetic when used in combination with a high concentration of N2O. Administration of 100% oxygen at the end of the procedure does not relate to the second gas effect.
  • • Option B. Second Gas Effect
  • • Option C. Hyperoxia : Administering 100% oxygen could potentially lead to hyperoxia, but in the context of the immediate post-anesthetic period, it is used as a preventive strategy against hypoxia, not as a cause of hyperoxia.
  • • Option C. Hyperoxia
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm : Bronchospasm is a potential adverse event related to anesthesia, but providing 100% oxygen post-extubation does not specifically address bronchospasm; it is more about ensuring adequate oxygenation.
  • • Option D. Bronchospasm
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The administration of 100% oxygen after discontinuing nitrous oxide and extubating the patient helps prevent diffusion hypoxia, which can occur due to the rapid outflow of nitrous oxide from the blood into the lungs, displacing oxygen.

questions.text: Which is the following inhalational agent is contraindicated in a patient with history of Epilepsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Enflurane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Isoflurane : This is generally considered safe in patients with epilepsy as it does not significantly increase seizure activity and has a relatively low proconvulsant risk.
  • • Option A. Isoflurane
  • • Option B. Enflurane : This agent is contraindicated in patients with epilepsy because it can induce seizures, especially at high concentrations or with rapid increases in concentration. It is known to provoke seizure-like EEG activity.
  • • Option B. Enflurane
  • • Option C. Halothane : Typically avoided in epilepsy because of its arrhythmogenic potential, but it is not specifically proconvulsant; however, there are better alternatives.
  • • Option C. Halothane
  • • Option D. Sevoflurane : Usually safe for use in patients with epilepsy; does not typically induce seizures.
  • • Option D. Sevoflurane
  • • Enflurane is the inhalational agent that is contraindicated in a patient with a history of epilepsy due to its proconvulsant effects.
  • • Enflurane is the inhalational agent that is contraindicated in a patient with a history of epilepsy due to its proconvulsant effects.
  • • Enflurane
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • In patients with a history of epilepsy, enflurane is contraindicated because it has a higher likelihood of inducing seizure activity, particularly at higher concentrations and with rapid increases in dose.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding desflurane is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes severe effects on kidney

options.label: B
options.text: It is structural analogue of isoflurane

options.label: C

questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Incorrect because desflurane is known for having least effects on kidney compared to other anesthetic agents.

  • • Educational objective
  • • Desflurane is closely related to isoflurane in its chemical structure but is characterized by its low solubility in blood, allowing for quick adjustments in anesthesia depth and faster recovery times post-surgery.

questions.text: In patients with both renal and hepatic failure, which muscle relaxant is preferred?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Atracurium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Atracurium: Correct. Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, a non-enzymatic process that is pH and temperature-dependent, as well as ester hydrolysis. These unique properties make it suitable for use in patients with renal and hepatic impairment because it does not rely on these organs for clearance.
  • • Option A. Atracurium:
  • • Option B. Pipecuronium: Incorrect. Pipecuronium is metabolized by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. In renal and hepatic failure, its clearance would be impaired.
  • • Option B. Pipecuronium:
  • • Option C. Vecuronium: Incorrect. Vecuronium is primarily broken down by the liver, and its metabolites are excreted by the kidneys. It would accumulate in the case of renal and hepatic failure.
  • • Option C. Vecuronium:
  • • Option D. Mivacurium: Incorrect. Mivacurium is rapidly hydrolyzed by plasma cholinesterases, but in the case of hepatic failure, where the production of cholinesterases might be reduced, its duration of action could be unpredictably prolonged.
  • • Option D. Mivacurium:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Atracurium is the muscle relaxant of choice in patients with renal and hepatic failure due to its Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis, which allow it to be safely metabolized without depending on kidney or liver function.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a minor elective laparoscopic procedure as part of a day-care surgery. Considering the need for rapid postoperative recovery and minimal residual sedation, which opioid is most suitable for intraoperative analgesia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Remifentanil

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Remifentanil: Correct. Remifentanil has a rapid onset and extremely short duration of action due to its rapid metabolism by plasma esterases. This makes it ideal for day-care surgeries where quick patient recovery and discharge are necessary.
  • • Option A. Remifentanil:
  • • Option B. Sufentanil: Incorrect. Although sufentanil is potent and has a rapid onset, it has a longer duration of action than remifentanil, which may not be ideal for day-care surgery due to prolonged sedation.
  • • Option B. Sufentanil:
  • • Option C. Morphine: Incorrect. Morphine has a longer duration of action and can lead to postoperative sedation and respiratory depression, which are not desirable in a day-care setting.
  • • Option C. Morphine:
  • • Option D. Butorphanol: Incorrect. Butorphanol can cause sedation and has a longer duration of action compared to remifentanil, making it less favorable for short procedures.
  • • Option D. Butorphanol:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • For day-care surgeries, remifentanil is the opioid of choice due to its ultra-short-acting properties, which allow for a rapid recovery and minimal postoperative sedation, enabling patients to be discharged sooner.

questions.text: In the perioperative setting, careful consideration is given to the management of psychiatric medications. Which of the following drugs is advised to be discontinued prior to surgery due to its anticholinergic effects and potential to affect heart rate and rhythm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Amitriptyline

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) known for its anticholinergic effects, which can lead to arrhythmias and other cardiovascular disturbances during surgery. The anticholinergic properties of TCAs can also affect the autonomic nervous system, potentially complicating the management of hemodynamics during anesthesia. Other options like sertraline (a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor), haloperidol (an antipsychotic), and lithium (a mood stabilizer) do not have the same degree of anticholinergic effects as TCAs and are not commonly required to be stopped before surgery.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Tricyclic antidepressants like amitriptyline should be closely evaluated and may need to be discontinued prior to surgery due to their significant anticholinergic effects and the potential for inducing cardiovascular complications during the perioperative period.

questions.text: When administering spinal anesthesia, the order in which nerve fibers are blocked is critical for the anesthesiologist to predict the effects on the patient. Which of the following represents the correct sequence of nerve fiber blockade post-spinal anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Autonomic > Sensory > Motor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • During spinal anesthesia, nerve fibers are affected in a characteristic sequence due to their size and myelination. Autonomic fibers are generally blocked first due to their smaller size and lack of myelin, followed by sensory fibers that transmit pain and temperature sensations. Motor fibers are larger and heavily myelinated, making them more resistant to the anesthetic agent, and thus, they are the last to be blocked.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The sequence of nerve fiber blockade following spinal anesthesia typically progresses from autonomic to sensory and finally to motor fibers. This order is essential for planning perioperative management and anticipating changes in patient condition during surgery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman with known coarctation of the aorta is scheduled for an elective caesarean section. Which anesthesia technique would be most appropriate to manage her case?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epidural Anesthesia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Spinal Anesthesia : Incorrect. Spinal anesthesia may lead to a sudden and significant decrease in systemic vascular resistance, which can be detrimental in patients with coarctation of the aorta.
  • • Option A. Spinal Anesthesia
  • • Option B. Epidural Anesthesia: Correct. Epidural anesthesia allows for a controlled and gradual onset of anesthesia, minimizing the risk of sudden hemodynamic changes, which is crucial in patients with coarctation of the aorta.
  • • Option B. Epidural Anesthesia:
  • • Option C. General Anesthesia: Incorrect. While general anesthesia can be safely used, it may not be the first choice due to the potential for hemodynamic instability upon induction and emergence.
  • • Option C. General Anesthesia:
  • • Option D. Local Anesthesia with nerve blocks: Incorrect. This method may not provide adequate analgesia for a caesarean section and does not address the potential hemodynamic changes associated with coarctation of the aorta.
  • • Option D. Local Anesthesia with nerve blocks:
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • In patients with coarctation of the aorta undergoing caesarean section, epidural anesthesia is preferred over spinal anesthesia to avoid sudden hemodynamic fluctuations and to provide stable and gradual onset of anesthesia.
  • • NOTE : ANY patient with cardiac valvular disease for LSCS preferred anesthesia is epidural anesthesia.

questions.text: During general anesthesia, Guedel’s stages are used to assess the depth of anesthesia. At which stage is surgery typically performed?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Stage III

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Guedel's stages of anesthesia describe the progressive effects of ether anesthesia in four stages. Stage III, known as Surgical Anesthesia, is divided into four planes. During this stage, the patient has adequate muscle relaxation and cessation of pain sensation, making it the optimal stage for performing surgery. The patient's breathing becomes regular, eye movements cease, and reflexes are diminished.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Surgery is typically performed during Stage III of Guedel's stages of anesthesia, as this is the stage where there is sufficient depth of anesthesia to ensure patient comfort and safety while providing optimal conditions for surgical manipulation.

questions.text: Which combination of maneuvers is typically employed to maintain an open airway in an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Chin lift, neck extension, and mouth inspection

options.label: B
options.text: Tongue pull, neck brace, and mouth opening

options.label: C
options.text: Jaw push, head stabilization, and nose pinch

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust are manual methods used to open and maintain the airway in an unconscious patient. The head tilt and chin lift maneuver extends the neck and lifts the chin, which helps to remove the tongue from the back of the throat, whereas the jaw thrust maneuver elevates the mandible without moving the cervical spine, beneficial if a cervical spine injury is suspected.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • To ensure an open airway in an unconscious patient without suspected cervical spine injury, the chin lift, head tilt, and jaw thrust maneuvers are recommended. These techniques are critical in emergency situations to prevent airway obstruction and ensure patient ventilation.

questions.text: What is the correct order of routes for the absorption of local anesthetics from fastest to slowest?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intercostal, Brachial, Epidural, Caudal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The rate of absorption of local anesthetics is largely determined by the vascularity of the injection site. Intercostal injections are absorbed the fastest due to the rich vascular supply of the intercostal spaces. This is followed by brachial plexus blocks, which are also highly vascularized. Epidural and caudal blocks are absorbed more slowly because of the comparatively lower vascularity of these spaces.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • When administering local anesthetics, it's crucial to consider the rate of systemic absorption to avoid toxicity. The intercostal route has the fastest absorption, followed by the brachial, with the epidural and caudal routes having slower absorption rates.

questions.text: In a patient exhibiting prolonged neuromuscular blockade after administration of rocuronium for muscle relaxation during surgery, which of the following is antidote to counteract its action?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent that is specifically designed to rapidly reverse the neuromuscular blockade induced by aminosteroid non-depolarizing muscle relaxants such as rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the muscle relaxant molecules, rendering them inactive, and effectively reversing the neuromuscular blockade.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Sugammadex is the antidote of choice for reversing the action of rocuronium, offering a rapid and efficient way to restore neuromuscular function in the postoperative setting.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is scheduled for middle ear surgery to repair a perforated tympanic membrane. Given the patient's need for tympanic graft placement, which of the following anesthetics should be specifically avoided?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) N2O (Nitrous Oxide)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In middle ear surgeries, particularly when tympanic grafts are used, it is important to avoid using N2O as an inhalation anesthetic. N2O can accumulate in closed air-containing spaces because it is more soluble in blood than nitrogen. As N2O diffuses into the middle ear space faster than nitrogen can diffuse out, it can lead to an increase in pressure which may displace the tympanic graft. Unlike N2O, Halothane, Isoflurane, and Ether do not significantly diffuse into closed air spaces and therefore pose less risk of graft dislodgement.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Avoid using nitrous oxide (N2O) as an anesthetic agent in middle ear surgeries involving tympanic grafts to prevent increased pressure that could compromise the surgical repair.

questions.text: Regarding non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: They cause muscle fasciculations upon administration

options.label: B
options.text: They are metabolized by plasma cholinesterase

options.label: C
options.text: They exhibit a shorter duration of action compared to depolarizing muscle relaxants

options.label: D
options.text: They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine

questions.correct_answer: D. They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) They can reverse the effects of neuromuscular blockade using neostigmine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as vecuronium, rocuronium, and cisatracurium, work by competitively inhibiting acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, preventing muscle contraction. They do not cause muscle fasciculations, which is a characteristic of depolarizing muscle relaxants like succinylcholine. Non-depolarizing agents can have varied durations of action, and some can be longer-lasting than depolarizing agents. Neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, increases the amount of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which can outcompete the non-depolarizing agent and reverse the muscle relaxation.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Neostigmine can be used to reverse the blockade caused by non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, making it an important agent in the recovery phase of anesthesia where muscle strength needs to be restored.

questions.text: In planning anesthesia for a 32-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension undergoing cholecystectomy, the anesthesiologist must choose the induction agent carefully. Which of the following induction agents should be avoided?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Ketamine is known for its sympathomimetic properties, which can lead to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure, making it a less ideal choice for hypertensive patients. Propofol, Midazolam, and Etomidate generally do not increase blood pressure and are safer alternatives in hypertensive individuals. Propofol and Etomidate are known for their hypotensive effects, and Midazolam is a benzodiazepine with minimal cardiovascular effects, making them more suitable for this patient.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Avoid using ketamine as an induction agent in patients with uncontrolled or significant hypertension due to its potential to raise blood pressure and heart rate.

questions.text: Which instrument is used to measure the depth of anesthesia ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bispectral index

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The Bispectral Index (BIS) is a monitoring method used to measure the effects of anesthetics on the brain and to estimate the level of consciousness. It uses electroencephalography (EEG) to produce a numerical scale, ranging from 0 (no electrical activity) to 100 (fully awake). This helps anesthesiologists ensure that a patient is neither under- nor over-sedated.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Capnograph - Measures the concentration of carbon dioxide in exhaled air, which is indicative of proper ventilation, not the depth of anesthesia.
  • • Option A. Capnograph
  • • Option B. Spirometer - Measures the volume of air entering and leaving the lungs.
  • • Option B. Spirometer
  • • Option D. Anesthesia machine - Delivers the anesthetic gases but does not measure the depth of anesthesia.
  • • Option D. Anesthesia machine
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The Bispectral Index (BIS) is the tool specifically designed to measure the depth of anesthesia, providing a single number that represents a patient's level of consciousness and helping guide anesthetic administration.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is considered the most predictive for a difficult intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upper lip bite test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mallampati classification relates the visibility of structures in the oral cavity with the tongue protruding; a higher class can indicate a potentially difficult airway.
  • • Option A. Mallampati classification
  • • Option B. Thyromental distance measures the distance from the thyroid notch to the mentum; a shorter distance can suggest a difficult airway due to anatomical constraints.
  • • Option B. Thyromental distance
  • • Option D. Sternomental distance measures the distance from the sternum to the mentum with the head extended; a smaller distance can be associated with a difficult airway.
  • • Option D. Sternomental distance
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The Upper lip bite test is a reliable and simple bedside test to predict difficult intubation; it evaluates both the mandibular space and the patient's ability to move the jaw and neck, which are crucial for intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of day care surgery for patients?

options.label: C

questions.text: In the context of anesthetic agents, what is a notable property of Xenon that differentiates it from many other agents?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low blood solubility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Xenon has a low blood-gas solubility coefficient, which contributes to rapid induction and recovery from anesthesia, making it a suitable agent for outpatient procedures where quick turnaround is desired.
  • • Xenon is non-explosive, making it safer to use in the operating room environment compared to some other anesthetic gases.
  • • It is not associated with cardiotoxic effects. In fact, Xenon has minimal hemodynamic effects and is often considered cardioprotective because it does not depress myocardial function.
  • • Slow induction and recovery are not characteristic of Xenon; these traits are more typical of agents with high solubility in blood.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Xenon is a noble gas used as an anesthetic agent that is characterized by its low blood solubility, leading to rapid induction and recovery, non-explosive nature, and minimal cardiotoxicity.

questions.text: In postoperative care, one of the most common concerns for patients is the risk of nausea and vomiting. The assessment of this risk can be calculated using a specific scoring system. Which of the following scores is used to predict the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Apfel Score

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Apfel Score is a widely recognized risk prediction tool for PONV. It takes into account factors such as patient-related elements (e.g., gender, history of motion sickness or PONV, nonsmoking status), and intraoperative variables (e.g., use of volatile anesthetics, duration of anesthesia). The higher the score, the greater the risk of PONV.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The Apfel Score is an important tool for assessing the risk of PONV, which helps in guiding prophylactic treatment and management strategies to improve patient comfort and satisfaction post-surgery.

questions.text: When assessing a patient's recovery after anesthesia, healthcare providers often refer to a specific score that evaluates various factors to determine readiness for discharge. Which scoring system is utilized to gauge a patient's post-anesthesia recovery status?

options.label: B
options.text: Post Anesthesia Care Unit Discharge Scoring System (PADSS)

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aldrete Score

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Aldrete Score is a commonly used recovery scoring system that evaluates a patient's mobility, respiration, circulation, consciousness, and color following anesthesia to determine their readiness for discharge from the Post Anesthesia Care Unit (PACU). The Apfel Score, on the other hand, is specific to predicting the risk of postoperative nausea and vomiting, not for assessing recovery from anesthesia.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The Aldrete Score is crucial for determining when a patient has recovered sufficiently from anesthesia to be safely discharged from the recovery room. It ensures that patients are adequately alert, have stable vital signs, and sufficient oxygen saturation levels, minimizing the risk of complications upon transfer to the ward or for discharge home.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation is scheduled for a total knee arthroplasty. He is currently managed on warfarin therapy, which has been held for the past 5 days. Preoperative labs show a platelet count of 85,000/mm^3, and he reports taking aspirin up until two days ago. He does not have a history of bleeding disorders, and no intravenous heparin has been administered. Considering his medication history and lab findings, which of the following would generally not be a contraindication to performing central neuraxial anesthesia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Recent use of aspirin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Central neuraxial blocks, including spinal and epidural anesthesia, are contraindicated in patients with significant thrombocytopenia.
  • • Option A.
  • • Option B. While recent use of aspirin does alter platelet function, it is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial blocks. Many practitioners will proceed with the block if the aspirin was discontinued at least a few days prior and if there are no other bleeding risks.
  • • Option B.
  • • Option C. Patients on oral anticoagulants like warfarin should have the medication held for an appropriate time before the procedure, and coagulation status should be normalized to reduce the risk of bleeding complications. This patient had his warfarin held 5 days prior, which typically allows for normalization of coagulation status.
  • • Option C.
  • • Option D. Intravenous heparin is a significant contraindication for central neuraxial blocks due to the high risk of bleeding and spinal hematoma formation, unless it has been discontinued and the aPTT has normalized.
  • • Option D.
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • Aspirin alters platelet function but is not an absolute contraindication for central neuraxial anesthesia, particularly if discontinued a few days before the procedure and in the absence of other bleeding risks. Each patient must be assessed individually, taking into consideration current guidelines and clinical judgment.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode at home. Her husband reports that she has been using a topical medication for her chronic back pain. Physical examination reveals cyanosis, and her pulse oximetry is low despite her breathing room air comfortably. Arterial blood gas shows a PaO2 within the normal range, but methemoglobin levels are elevated. She has no history of epilepsy and does not take any antiepileptic medications. questions.text: A 25-year-old male with traumatic brain injury is admitted to the ICU and requires deep sedation. He has been on a high-dose intravenous infusion of an anesthetic agent for several days.
